Never have I been so distracted with the backdrop of a game.  The world creation, and aesthetic of Infinite has raised the bar for games I will play in the future.  The gameplay can be one dimensional at times, facing the same types of mobs over & over & over & over again.  The new plasmids (salts) are refreshing to the series, and matched the new city they created.  Story wise... play for yourself

DLC:
ðŸ‘ [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/n1phantom/recommended/214931/]BioShock Infinite: Burial at Sea - Episode 1[/url]
ðŸ‘ [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/n1phantom/recommended/214932/]BioShock Infinite: Burial at Sea - Episode 2[/url]

I have absolutely no idea what the hell this game was about, and watching videos has not helped. The other Bioshock games were confusing too, but the story here is absolutely mental; nothing made sense, even when the ending tried to explain it all. I literally got this whole game spoiled out of curiosity seeing a let's play several years back, yet that took nothing away from the experience, and I was still left stunned; it's that bizarre. 

The game is really fun though, and still looks great. Columbia is really pretty to look at, and I feel it's just as good as Rapture, plus the world building, especially in the intro, is really well done. The horror elements in this are really cool too, and surprisingly, you get an escort companion that isn't completely useless and actually helps you defeat enemies and get supplies. Great game; check it out, but prepare for a mind f-ck.

Bioschock: Infinite is vastly different from the first two Bioshock games in terms of theme.  While the first two are set miles below the ocean in Rapture, Bioshock: Infinite takes place in the floating city of Columbia.  Infinite shares similar gameplay elements from the first two games, so if you are a fan of that, more is here, and it is improved upon greatly.  The story also pulls from some of the plot devices that the first game utilized, which also might be something that fans of the first game enjoyed.  This is an enjoyable experience on its own, and while it may not live up to the first two games, it provides something unique from them that is still worth playing.  Some even feel that this title is superior to the others.  The pc port is done much better this time as well!
this game was really good i definitly recomend it to everyone who is interested.

Ð”Ð¾Ð»Ð¶ÐµÐ½ Ð±Ñ‹Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð¸Ð½Ñ‚ÐµÑ€ÐµÑÐµÐ½ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ñ‚ÐµÑ… ÐºÑ‚Ð¾ Ð»ÑŽÐ±Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ñ…Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾ÑˆÐµÐµ Ð¸ Ð³Ð»ÑƒÐ±Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð¼Ñ‹ÑÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð½Ñ‹Ðµ Ð¸ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð¸.
æˆ‘åªæƒ³è¯´ï¼Œä¼Šä¸½èŽŽç™½æ˜¯æˆ‘è€å©†ï¼Œä¸æŽ¥å—ä»»ä½•åé©³ã€‚

This game went through harsh changes and development process, yet Irrational Games manage to create a game that yet again feels alive and breathing. The true gem of this game is its story. A story about a man, a lighthouse, and a city. A story that will be remembered for years to come.  

Aside from the story, this game has good pace. There's not a lot of quiet moment or loud moment but a perfect mix between the two. Gunfight feels awesome with vigors and the weapons feel punchy, my personal favorite is the shotgun. Elizabeth, your companion is not just a companion. She also helps you in gunfight such as throwing ammo, healthpacks and vigors and even frequently gives you money. Also you don't need to watch over her the entire time because she can takes of herself. Also she interacts with the her surroundings, occasionaly looking, commenting or sometimes eating. This moments with Elizabeth in gunfights or in normal situation makes you cares about her instead of getting annoyed. The story also shaped around her which truly refined this game to its finest.

Overall I give this game a Booker Catch! / 10
